change.item: Encoded finding aid completed by Abi Parker.
Batch update to change subject links.

did.abstract: The Conrad mss., 1886-1983, consists of the papers of novelist Joseph Conrad, 1857-1924.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Many collections are housed offsite; retrieval requires advance notice. Please make an appointment a minimum of one week in advance of your visit.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Józef Teodor Conrad Korzeniowski was born in the city of Berdyczów, Ukraine and raised by parents of Polish descent. As a young man he joined first the French Merchant Marine, then an English mercantile ship, and spent fifteen years traveling as a seaman to Africa and other part of the world. He became a British citizen while at sea, changing his name to Joseph Conrad; and when he returned he moved to England and lived the rest of his life there. Conrad wrote the most significant of his novels in the English language, including Lord Jim (1900), Heart of Darkness (1902), Nostromo (1904), The Secret Agent (1907), and Chance (1914).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into the following series: I. Correspondence; II. Clippings; III. Gontran Goulden; IV. Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Major correspondents from the Correspondence series in this collection can be found in the indexing terms.

The Gontran Goulden series contains materials from Goulden's archive detailing his personal and professional relationship with Conrad, including items detailing his dramatic adaptation of The Secret Agent in 1921.

Also included in the collection are notes for speeches given by Conrad in the United States, notes on his books, the short story "Because of the Dollars," a late draft of "Part III" of Suspense, a review of John Galsworthy's The Man of Property, Conrad's 1912 article "Some Aspects of the Admirable Inquiry into the Loss of the Titanic," William McFee's "The Ideal Wife of a Genius," Ford Madox Ford's introduction to The Sisters, two pen and ink sketches, Sir David Low's crayon caricature of Conrad, and photographs.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Photography and digitization may be restricted for some collections. Copyright restrictions may apply. Before publishing, researchers are responsible for securing permission from all applicable rights holders, then filling out the Permission to Publish form.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Conrad mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Some folders may include writings, photographs, and other accompanying materials.

unittitle.title: The Richard Curle Collection of Conrad.

did.unittitle: Some Aspects of the English Titanic Inquiry. Author's manuscript. The English Review

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discusses John Conrad's recollections of his father's early life

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Augotraph letter signed from Conrad to Jackson Holbrook thanking him for his article on Conrad

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ten autograph letters signed from Conrad to Michael James Holland

did.unittitle: Holt, Lawrence Durning and G. Jean-Aubry

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes four letters, three autograph and one typed, by Conrad to Holt of the Ocean Steam Ship Company about establishing a training sailing ship for the merchant service and the resulting "Memorandum" (see "Memorandum" in Writings series). Also includes two letters, one autograph and one typed, by G. Jean-Aubry to Holt about Conrad's "Memorandum"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes 10 autograph letters signed from Conrad to Newbolt concerning the grant to Conrad of 500 pounds from the Royal Bounty Fund. Also includes 24 autograph letters and cards from Rothenstein to Newbolt regarding financial assistance for Conrad, as well as 1 letter from Alice Rothenstein to Newbolt, 7 from Edmund Gosse to Newbolt on his work on Conrad's behalf, 2 draft letters from Newbolt to Conrad, a letter from the Prime Minister's office confirming the grant to Conrad, and a bank account book in the names of Newbolt and Rothenstein recording the payment in instlaments of the grant to Conrad along with 22 cheques and 2 books of cheque stubs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twenty-three letters signed from Conrad to Christopher Sandeman about the progress of World War One and related international affairs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six autograph letters from Conrad to Ted Sanderson and his fiancee Helen Watson about Sanderson and Watson's relationship. Also includes three letters from Sanderson to Watson and four letters from Watson to Sanderson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed to unknown recipient responding to a letter of appreciation

did.unittitle: "Memorandum: on the scheme for fitting out a sailing-ship for the purpose of perfecting the training of Merchant Service Officers belonging to the Port of Liverpool"
"Polish Question: Note on the joint Protectorate of the Western Powers and Russia"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript leaf with autograph revisions
